title: Everyone should try support and jungle
body:
I'm not saying in ranked. Or as your main. Or that it should be compulsory. But I think everyone, for their own good, should play 5-10 games as support, and 5-10 games as jungle a season, at least. Not mandatory, just by choice they should go and do it. And not as a troll pick, as a normal, meta support/jungler. These roles teach you so much about team play, objective play and reliance on your allies. On top of that, you will understand these roles better, be able to play with them better, rage at them less, and learn useful skills. You will probably get better at warding, playing safe and general map awareness.

Real talk though. Autofill, like it or hate it, you will get support and jungle sometimes. I am a jungle main, but I picked up playing support a lot in normals, so that if I get autofilled to support, it's cool. Everyone, everyone should know how to support. It is a cornerstone role, you will be forced to play it sometimes, and it teaches you more about map awareness and warding than arguably any other role. Most people should know how to jungle, it is crucial to objectives and swaying lane balance. More importantly, you will know what a jungler must do, and how they function, so in your primary role in ranked, you can know what to expect from them, and how to work with them better.

This isn't to thrash anybody, or say any role is bad. It's just saying, autofill and good teamwork, demand that we all get better at support and jungle, because these are huge roles that function totally different from top carry, mid carry, adc carry last hitters. And if you don't know how to jungle or support, you can't just fudge it. It's not like a mid main getting top and still knowing the basics of laning and last hitting, picking somebody like swain, vlad or cass top to get by. It is a totally different aspect of the game. Learn it, for your good, your team's good, and your ELO.

How would you recommend starting? I agree with what you are saying but I never like to actually go and play as a jungle in a pvp because I know I would suck and feed the enemy, causing my team to flame me.

You can pick a simple champion that scales well into the late game. Often times, unless you are in very high elo, you won't be getting punished or invaded because the enemy jungler doesn't really know what to do with jungle. Jungle isn't the role of "farming things that aren't in lanes and ganking lanes". Junglers aren't the laner's whores. Junglers are there to mainly secure objectives, provide vision that laner's can't because they have to keep their lanes in check, they are there to apply pressure to laners, even by not being visible to the enemy minimap. In general, jungle is a game of strategy much like chess and requires a lot of thought into how the lanes will play out, when is the optimal time to gank a lane (usually you look in lanes to see which way they are pushing) and where & when the enemy jungler will show up, as well as, which skirmishes you can win. It's really a role that isn't made by the player's individual mechanics as much as it is made by how experienced and smart the jungler is.

1) Pick two junglers that are not super popular (i.e. Zac has a 50% ban rate now, so not a good choice). They should be different roles. A couple "easier" junglers from various roles: Amumu and Sejuani (tank), Skarner and Udyr (off-tank), Jarvan IV and Wukong (AD bruiser/initiator), Fiddlesticks (AP).

2) Find a guide for your champ that gives you a reasonable idea of your jungle route, runes, masteries, and early buys. You don't need to buy runes to match up perfectly, but good runes can make the difference between a full clear and dying on your second camp.

3) Start out in custom games- no pvp, no bots, no other people. Go through until you can clear as much of the jungle as is reasonable for your champ. If you die early or have to back super early in a pvp game, you won't learn as much as you should. So make sure you can do a "normal" clear for your champ without help.

And you're ready for pvp! If you do do bot games, I'd avoid getting used to ganking them. The bad habits you can pick up from getting used to bot reactions to getting ganked are more severe than for laners, in my opinion.

Last comment: There's a great guide on MOBAFire for general jungling. The specific details about the champions are 3.5 years old, but the general analysis style is great. If you enjoy reading, check out http://www.mobafire.com/league-of-legends/build/who-is-your-jungler-and-what-does-he-do-114118. Think about the points that are used to analyze different junglers (i.e. clear speed, pre-6 and post-6 ganks, etc.). Think about how you can capitalize on those strengths in your games as a jungler. And when you return to your primary roles, keep that information in mind too when deciding how to play. ("My bot lane partner and I are super aggressive champs! But the enemy jungler is Xin Zhao and ours is Warwick, so pushing up will get us killed regardless of how dominant we seem to be in 2v2.")
